name: heat production, borehole heat exchanger, brine-water heat pump 10kW | heat, brine-water heat pump 10kW | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5675/documentation

This dataset represents the production of heat with a brine-water heat pump and a borehole heat exchanger for an average one family house. The dataset is based on a brine-water heat pump unit operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions. The brine-water heat pump has a heat capacity of 10 kW and a Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) of 3.9 (for the year 1998). Data for the estimation of SPF is based on a field study for Swiss heat pumps and on various literature. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for the heat pump and 50 years for the borehole heat exchanger. This dataset is based on the following reference values: for the average one family house a heating requirement of 10 kW, a heat distribution system (low-temperature system) of 50/40°C and a heat supply of approximately 20.000 kWh with 2.000 operating hours were assumed. Furthermore, a system with a heating output of 10,25 kW (at a supply temperature of 40°C), a mean cooling capacity of 8,25 kW (to dimension the borehole heat exchanger) and a extraction performance of 55 W/m were chosen. The system is assumed to be operated without an auxiliary heating system. 

From geothermal energy entering the borehole heat exchanger.

This activity ends with heat at the brine-water heat pump with a life time of 20 years. This dataset includes emissions of refrigerant R134a during operation and the UCTE electricity mix. This dataset doesn´t include the heat distribution in the one family house, nor a buffer heat storage.

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is based on a heat pump unit operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) is an important figure which indicates the ratio between heat amount at heat pump (respectively at storage if available) and specific demand for electricity of the heat pump (incl. all common auxiliaries). New geothermal heat pumps in Europe achieve Seasonal Performance Factors of 4 or even higher. This is due to improved components and lower temperatures in the distribution system (below 35°C) based on improved heat insulation.;;The Seasonal Performance Factors are estimated, based on a comprehensive field study for heat pump installations in Switzerland. For this dataset a SPF of 3,9 for brine-water heat pumps operated in Switzerland in the year 1998 was assumed.;;References:;Holozan H. (2002): Heat pumps and the environment. Proceedings of the 7th International Energy Agency Conference on Heat Pumping Technologies, Beijing, China, May 19-22, 2002.;;Erb M and Hubacher P: Field analysis of Swiss heat pump installations. IEA Heat Pump Centre Newsletter. Volume 19 - No. 1/2001. Available from: www.heatpumpcentre.org
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is based on a brine-water heat pump with a heat capacity of 10 kW operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. With a heating capacity of 10 kW and operating hours of 2000 h/a the brine-water heat pump produces approx. 1,44E06 MJ of heat within a life time of 20 years. The reciprocal value indicates the amount of heat pumps required to produce one MJ of useful heat. Life time of the borehole heat exchanger is assumed to be 50 years, i.e. the infrastructure is decreased by a factor of 2.5.

flow.name: heat, brine-water heat pump 10kW
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description:
Estimation. A 10 kW brine-water heat pump unit for an average one family house is used. 

Brine-water heat pumps use geothermal energy by extracting the heat stored in the ground with a borehole heat exchanger. The heat is withdrawn from the soil through a closed-loop system situated in the tube and is fed to the heat pump. As heat-conveying fluid, i.e. brine, in the majority of cases water is used compounded with 25 % to 35% of antifreezing agent. The heat pump then transforms the heat through a second circuit to an appropriate temperature level for low-temperature heating systems. Brine-water heat pumps are more expensive but have a higher annual coefficient of performance compared to air-water heat pumps, i.e. high quality energy is used in a more efficient way. According to Lovvorn and Hess life time of the heat pump is 20 years.

Further references:

Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Paper. Proceedings of Joint HPC and IPUHPC Workshop "Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings," 10-11 October 2001. Arnhem, The Netherlands. CD-ROM: "Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings," Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.

Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Power Point Presentation. CD-ROM: "Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings," Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
Estimation. The UCTE electricity mix is used. Seasonal Performance Factor of 3.9 (in the year 1998) is estimated. The reciprocal value of the Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) indicates the required amount of electricity in MJ per MJ of heat, at heat pump (divided by the factor of 3.6 to convert into kWh).

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Estimation. Borehole heat exchangers basically consist of coaxial or U-shaped polyethylene tubes and are installed vertically in the soil, usually at a depth of 50 up to 250 meters. Thereby the soil serves as heat source. 

For  a borehole heat exchanger for an average one family house two U-shaped polyethylene tubes are installed in a borehole in the ground with a diameter of about 12 cm and a depth of 150 meters. Life time is assumed to be 50 years.

exchanges.description: Estimation. During operation leakage losses occur, which result in refrigerant emissions to air. In Frischknecht (Appendix Tab. 6.1) refrigerant losses between 5 % and 8 % are indicated, based on four different literature sources; one literature source indicates refrigerant losses between 1 % and 4 %. In this dataset 6 % of refrigerant losses are assumed with an uncertainty of SDg2  = 1,7 due to the range of literature values. Assuming operating hours of 2000 h/a the heat pump with a heat capacity of 10 kW produces 72.000 MJ/a. With a filling quantity of 3 kg refrigerant emissions of 2.5E-06 kg/MJ can be estimated. Taking a life time of 20 years into account, this amounts to 3,6 kg. Thus, on average losses during operation are bigger than the filling quantity.
